Sentence: Superconductivity in magnesium-diboride (MgB 2 ) was discovered in 2001 and today its industrial production offers a viable candidate for the design of large-scale applications operating at temperatures between 4.2 K and 20 K.
However, because of its relative low critical temperature (less than 40 K), it is necessary to operate MgB 2 devices in a liquid or gaseous helium environment.

Finally, its low cost compared to ReBCO tapes is an advantage, although this is somewhat counterbalanced by its much lower critical temperature (â 39 K vs. â 90 K), usually attained by working in a gaseous helium environment.
Today MgB 2 superconducting wires can be manufactured in long lengths at low cost, which makes this material a good candidate for large scale applications.
